text: my name is grishma i'm a startup
solutions architecture manager i lead
our early stage and y combinator
solutions architecture teams
prior to joining aws i was in college i
studied computer science and i was
looking to go into a more traditional
path of software engineering when i met
with my amazon recruiter she started
talking about the solutions architecture
role it was a role that was pretty new
and i immediately was very interested in
it because it combined a lot of my
interests and my skill sets and it was
something that i thought i would enjoy
and get into a lot more than the
software engineering role
when i started at amazon i was a part of
the tech u program which is a six month
training program for solutions
architects to get ramped up it was great
because i got to learn not only about
aws but also how we as solutions
architects work with customers in the
field how we do whiteboarding meetings
how we build pocs and how we have
customer conversations i chose the
program because i knew that six months
of training would be really helpful for
a world that was that i wasn't super
familiar with
i learned a lot from our founders
industries that i haven't really spent a
lot of time thinking about like space
i'm a customer that's building operation
systems for space exploration and other
complex workflows so it's been really
interesting getting to work with them
and getting to learn about new fields
and industries that i haven't worked in
before
the startup team i would say that we do
operate kind of like a very large
startup we are very scrappy we're always
thinking about new ways of how we can
engage with our customers my advice for
candidates that are going through the
interview process or thinking about
applying to amazon would be to be open
about the kind of roles that you're
considering for example like i mentioned
i wasn't really too sure about the
switches architecture rule i wasn't
familiar with what the day to day would
look like but there are plenty of
amazonians that are willing to help and
talk to you and so you can learn a
little bit more about the role and what
it looks like and be open to kind of the
roles that you want to apply to the
roles that you're considering
